discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I think the answer should be D as the question suggests that the code for the new feature has not been written yet ("...needs to be developed...").

The usual git workflow is to create a new branch where the new feature can be written in isolation without disturbing the existing code until it has been properly debugged, tested, approved for release etc.

Only after all that has happened, then it can be merged with the main branch of the existing code.

So:
git branch [newfeaturename]
git checkout [newfeaturename]
...write code, test code etc...
git checkout main
git merge [newfeaturename]

comments.content: Agree, why would you immediately merge after you cloned, with development not even having been started...

questions.question_text:
After cloning a remote repository, a new feature of that project needs to be developed and integrated into the next major release.
Which of the following is the first Git operation to run to begin working on this new feature immediately after the clone?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Ok, am I alone in thinking it could be D due to the SELinux security context difference between /var/www/html (which has the context httpd_t) and /var/www/html/website (which has the context default_t)?

Yes the ls -l output shows a root:root for ownership but the dir has r-x permissions for everyone and the file has read permissions for everyone... so the webserver should be able to access the files it needs to serve even if the ownership of the /var/www tree probably should be changed to the www user & group. Something else is stopping access to the file and that's probably SELinux

questions.question_text:
A Linux administrator is configuring a server to log security events for the ping command while allowing the request to occur. The Linux server is using AppArmor to manage its security services.
Which of the following commands is the BEST option?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Letting AppArmor log the event but still allowing it to occur, that's A) aa-complain /bin/ping surely?

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct
https://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/kinetic/en/man8/aa-complain.8.html
In complain mode, any violations of the profile will be logged but not blocked.

questions.question_text:
A systems administrator wants to disable the isofs module on the server.
Which of the following will allow the administrator to check if the isofs module is currently in use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D) lsmod

it is lsmod that shows a list of currently loaded kernel modules, their size in memory, how many processes are using them and which other kernel modules depend on them

Selected Answer: D
D:
lsmod list all current kernels

https://linuxize.com/post/lsmod-command-in-linux/
The lsmod command shows a list of the currently loaded kernel modules

https://linuxize.com/post/modprobe-command-in-linux/
The modprobe command allows you to add and remove Linux kernel modules

choices.A: The filesystem is out of inodes.
choices.B: The filesystem is out of file space.
choices.C: The filesystem is not configured for the user to write to it.
choices.D: The filesystem does not have a group write permission.

discussion.content:
A) The filesystem is out of inodes

Look at the output of df -i in the question. The column headings have been cropped out but they should be
Filesystem, Inodes, IUsed, IFree, IUse%, Mounted on
So the 4th column of the output shows the number of inodes free... which is 0, therefore the drive has run out of inodes.

Selected Answer: A
I hate these questions. At least 2 of these answers are right. But if we answered it the way they questioned it, the user is not able to WRITE because there is no WRITE rights. At the same time, the filesystem ran out of inodes. Which most people agree with..I can't wait to pass this test and move out of CompTIA LOL..

Selected Answer: A
A is the answer.

Selected Answer: A
A- out of inodes
